Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Magnetic Phase Transitions in Intercalated Dichalcogenides
Award.AbstractNarration:
****Technical Abstract****
Transition-metal dichalcogenides such as titanium disulfide possess a layered crystal structure consisting of atomic trilayers stacked along the c axis. The trilayers are weakly bound by van der Waals forces. Pure dichalcogenides exhibit interesting properties such as charge density waves and superconductivity. Foreign atoms can be introduced into the interlayer gaps; this is called intercalation. In this project, the effects of intercalating magnetic ions on the properties of dichalcogenide materials will be experimentally investigated. By varying the type and content of the intercalant and the nature of the host, competition between magnetic phases will be controlled and transitions between phases studied. Quasi-one-dimensional nanostructures will also be fabricated and studied. The outcome of the project is a better understanding of how structure and interactions determine magnetic ground states in the dichalcogenides and other materials such as manganites. Undergraduates will be deeply involved in sample fabrication, measurements and data analysis. The efficacy of undergraduate research for training students in scientific reasoning and writing will be assessed using nationally recognized instruments. High-school students from underrepresented groups will also be immersed and mentored in the research environment.

****Non-Technical Abstract****
Transition-metal dichalcogenides (for example, titanium disulfide) have a crystal structure consisting of layers of atoms (three atoms thick) stacked along a direction perpendicular to the layers. The layers are weakly bonded, which permits the introduction of new atoms between the layers in a process called intercalation. The intercalated material has properties that reflect both those of the host and the inserted atoms. Thus, one can control the overall properties of the material by controlling the type and number of intercalant atoms. Such tunable materials could be very useful in new magnetic and electronic devices in which specific characteristics could be engineered by controlling the properties of the intercalant. This project will investigate a variety of intercalated dichalcogenides, including newly fabricated nanotubes. Magnetic and electronic properties will be carefully measured to obtain a thorough understanding of the behavior of these materials. Their potential for applications will then be evaluated. Undergraduate students will play an integral part in every aspect of the research. The efficacy of undergraduate research for training students in scientific reasoning and writing will be assessed. High-school students from underrepresented groups will also be immersed and mentored in the research environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Transition-metal dichalcogenides (for example, tantalum disulfide) have a crystal structure consisting of layers of atoms (three atoms thick) stacked along a direction perpendicular to the layers. The layers are weakly bonded, which permits the introduction of atoms between the layers in a process called intercalation. The intercalated material has properties that reflect both those of the host and the inserted atoms. Thus, one can control the overall properties of the material by controlling the type and number of intercalant atoms. In this project, tantalum disulfide was intercalated with manganese, which gave the system magnetic properties. The material was made in the form of nanotubes and crystals.

Extensive measurements of the magnetic properties of the nanotubes showed that for relatively high concentrations of manganese, the nanotube system became ferromagnetic, i.e., it behaved like a strong magnet, at temperatures close to that of liquid nitrogen. When the temperature was further lowered, the magnetic behavior transitioned to that of a cluster glass, which is a magnetic analog of ordinary glass. This kind of behavior is due to randomness in the arrangement of the manganese atoms in the intercalated nanotubes. For particular concentrations of manganese, the transitions to the ferromagnetic phase and then to the cluster-glass phase are very close together. We have found that when the transitions are very close together, they can be distinguished by using different magnetic measurements that are more sensitive to one phase or the other. We have also discovered that the cluster-glass phase of the intercalated nanotubes has similar characteristics to the behavior of systems consisting of high concentrations of magnetic nanoparticles. At low concentrations of manganese, there is no transition to ferromagnetism; only a cluster-glass phase appears at low temperatures.

A crystalline sample with a concentration of manganese slightly higher than the highest concentration in the nanotubes was also investigated. In this case, only a transition to ferromagnetism was seen; there was no cluster-glass transition. Data for lower manganese concentrations in crystalline samples are needed for a full comparison with the nanotube systems.

Thirteen undergraduate students participated in and were supported by this project. In addition, three high-school students whose parents did not attend college conducted scientific investigations with the support of this project. In a survey, the undergraduate students assessed their learning gains in laboratory skills and data analysis to be substantial and were very positive about the experience of being involved in research. Groups of low-income and/or minority high-school students were guided through activities involving electrical and magnetic phenomena in two-hour sessions during the summers of 2013-2016. During these sessions, the students interacted with undergraduate researchers and discussed their plans for college. 

Two undergraduate participants in this project who have graduated are pursuing graduate studies in physics. One graduate is teaching high-school physics. Others are employed in the private sector. Two of the three high-school student participants have majored in physics or engineering in college. The third also plans to major in physics or engineering when he matriculates next year.
